thread.title_full: Preah Vihear temple in Cambodia now safe to visit - Telegraph

author: Natalie Paris
title: Preah Vihear temple in Cambodia now safe to visit
text: A ninth century Angkorian temple on the boarder between Thailand and Cambodia is now considered safe to visit after being the subject of conflict between the two countries since 2008. Soldiers from the Cambodia army have been guarding the Preah Vihear temple, surrounded in jungle and bearing similarities to Angkor Wat , for the last few years. The few tourists that made it to the far north of Cambodia to visit the site were required to check in at an army base on arrival. The temple, declared a World Heritage site in 2008, lies just 100 metres from the border with Thailand, a border that was created at the end of the Second World War. Shortly after, Thai soldiers descended on the temple and a battle ensued with Cambodian troops, with the temple becoming a flashpoint for hostilities in the years that followed. A Cambodian solider guards the grounds of the 11th-century Preah Vihear temple as tensions remain high on both sides of the border Photo: GETTY IMAGES In November 2013 the International Court of Justice unanimously decided that the land around Preah Vihear belonged to Cambodia and that Thailand should withdraw its troops. • Angkor: an interactive map of Cambodia's must-see temples “Having lived in Cambodia and visited a vast number of the temples, the one that towers above all of them amongst my memories is Prasat Preah Vihear,” said Mark Hotham a senior specialist at Audley Travel. He visited just before the dispute with Thailand worsened and the Foreign Office advice changed to prevent British tourists from visiting. Buddhist monk shows a piece of shrapnel found at the 11th-century Preah Vihear temple Photo: REUTERS “Set on a promontory 500 metres above the Cambodian plains in the far north of the country, the temple’s remote and stunning location lends it a majesty that even Angkor Wat falls in the shadow of,” he said. “Sitting on the steps of the temple at dusk with just a couple of local monks for company as the village cooking fires light up 500 metres below is one of the most resounding memories of all of my travels through Asia. • Angkor bans naked photos in new code of conduct “No doubt the Cambodian government will wish to cash in on it now so I advise taking the opportunity to see it before the special ambience of the site is spoiled.” The Foreign Office lifted its travel ban on the Preah Vihear temple area and the Ta Krabey/Ta Moan temple area yesterday. A Cambodian soldier polishes his boots at the 11th-century Preah Vihear temple Photo: REUTERS Audley (01993 838 100; audleytravel.com ) offers a new eight-night Thailand and Cambodia itinerary to include a night at Preah Vihear , starting at £3,685 per person. It also includes two nights in Siem Reap in order to visit the temples at Angkor . • Angkor: an interactive map of Cambodia's must-see temples Telegraphtravel Follow @telegraphtravel Telegraph Travel Collection»
